title: How to Sew an Envelope Back Pillow

steps.headline: Create your pattern.
steps.description: Making sure that the corners are perfect, use a triangle ruler, measure and draw a rectangle that measures 16" x 36". You can add a seam allowance if you'd like. Cut along the lines and you have your pattern.

steps.headline: Cut your fabric.
steps.description: Lay your fabric down and make sure it's smooth with no wrinkles. Put your pattern over top the fabric, and pin it down to keep it in place. Cut right along the edges of the pattern. You should have a perfect 16" x 36" rectangle of fabric.

steps.headline: Mark your fabric.
steps.description: Make markings 10" from the short ends of the fabric, on each side. If you don't have marking chalk, you can cut a small snip in the fabric to mark it.

steps.headline: Get ready to sew.
steps.description: Thread your sewing machine, making sure the needle is sharp. Set up your iron and ironing board for pressing the hems.

steps.headline: Press the hems.
steps.description: Measure and fold down 1/4" along the short ends of the fabric, folding the wrong sides together. Press with iron, and repeat so that the raw edge is enclosed.

steps.headline: Sew the hems down.
steps.description: Keep your stitches as close to the loose edges as possible. Repeat on both ends.

steps.headline: Fold your fabric.
steps.description: Fold the hemmed edge of the fabric in toward the center until you reach the mark you made 10" from the end. Make sure the fabric is folded with the right sides together. Repeat for the other side. The hems should overlap each other in the center. Pin the sides in place.

steps.headline: Sew seams in both edges, making sure to remove the pins as you reach them.
steps.description: If your sewing machine has a zig zag setting, zig-zag the raw edges to keep them from fraying.

steps.headline: Press the new seams.
steps.description: This sets the stitches into the fabric. Turn the pillow right side out and then press all around the edges.

steps.headline: Use over your couch pillows, now that your pillow is complete.
steps.description: Or you can buy a 16" x 16" pillow form to place inside!

Cut along the lines and you have your pattern. Cut your fabric. Lay your fabric down and make sure it's smooth with no wrinkles. Put your pattern over top the fabric, and pin it down to keep it in place. Cut right along the edges of the pattern. You should have a perfect 16" x 36" rectangle of fabric. Mark your fabric. Make markings 10" from the short ends of the fabric, on each side. If you don't have marking chalk, you can cut a small snip in the fabric to mark it. Get ready to sew. Thread your sewing machine, making sure the needle is sharp. Set up your iron and ironing board for pressing the hems. Press the hems. Measure and fold down 1/4" along the short ends of the fabric, folding the wrong sides together. Press with iron, and repeat so that the raw edge is enclosed. Sew the hems down. Keep your stitches as close to the loose edges as possible. Repeat on both ends. Fold your fabric. Fold the hemmed edge of the fabric in toward the center until you reach the mark you made 10" from the end. Make sure the fabric is folded with the right sides together. Repeat for the other side. The hems should overlap each other in the center. Pin the sides in place. Sew seams in both edges, making sure to remove the pins as you reach them. If your sewing machine has a zig zag setting, zig-zag the raw edges to keep them from fraying. Press the new seams. This sets the stitches into the fabric. Turn the pillow right side out and then press all around the edges. Use over your couch pillows, now that your pillow is complete. Or you can buy a 16" x 16" pillow form to place inside!
